awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: Shedding Light on firefly phylogenetic systematics and the evolution of their carnal signal types
awd_abstract_narration:
Few organisms capture human attention and imagination better than fireflies. Yet, we know exceptionally little about the >2000 species of fireflies. Fireflies play important roles in medical sciences and evolutionary, ecological, and behavioral studies. New species are described regularly while many others are under imminent threat of extinction. What is lacking is a tree of life (i.e., a phylogeny) for fireflies to help organize all species and explore their evolutionary history. After constructing this tree, the research will explore the evolution of the different courtship signals of fireflies (flashes, glows, or chemical odors), while exploring the structure and shape of the organ that produces the light. In addition, the research will determine the trade-off in the size and shape of sensors (eyes and antenna), when the mating signal changes from odors to light (glows or flashes) and vice versa. With these data, the signals and behavior of fossil fireflies and museum specimens can be predicted and specific questions about their evolution can be answered. The project will train graduate students and include outreach and citizen science efforts to actively engage the public. Websites, videos, and identification keys will assist both scientists and the public to better understand the diversity and ecology of fireflies across the US and world. 

Bioluminescence is widely scattered across the tree of life. Fireflies (Coleoptera, Lampyridae) are the most diverse, well-known, and well-studied bioluminescent group. The bioluminescence and flash patterns of adult fireflies are often used as textbook example of species-specific courtship signals. However, we still remain in the dark about their phylogenetic relationships and the evolution of their sexual communication systems. We will reconstruct a phylogeny across the worldwide diversity of fireflies. The diversity of their sexual signals, light producing organs, and signal receptors make these beetles an ideal lineage to study how the evolution of traits associated with sexual signaling and may have affected species diversity. This research has three major goals: 1) reconstruct the first large-scale phylogenetic hypotheses for Lampyridae based on extensive taxon sampling (~350 taxa) using both NGS and morphological data sets; 2) characterize the morphological phenotypes associated with the three main types of sexual communication based on light organ, eye, and antennal morphology of extant and fossil taxa, as well as of rare museum specimens; 3) reconstruct the evolutionary history of firefly sexual signal modes, and test for relationships between signal mode and species diversification. This research will catalyze studies of the Lampyridae and provide important empirical data on the role of sexual signaling and diversification that will be of general use to researchers across numerous disciplines.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF funded project generated a family tree of the beetle family Lampyridae, also known as lightning bugs or fireflies. This advanced our understanding of how fireflies are related to each other, how their communication systems evolved, and how the different sensors on their antennae help fireflies perceive their world.

Fireflies occur worldwide with more than 2500 species in 11 subfamilies. This project used DNA sequences of 339 firefly species in 10 firefly subfamilies (and 3 close firefly relatives) to generate the most comprehensive firefly family tree to date. This tree helped us gain new insights into how fireflies are related to each other, how they spread across the world, and how some of their key characteristics, e.g. their famous glows or flash signals evolved. These signals are used by adult fireflies to identify potential mates and are highly variable between species to reduce costly mating mistakes. For example, many firefly species use species-specific flash patterns (number of flashes repeated in specific time intervals) to recognize each other, other firefly species use long glows, and some fireflies (dark fireflies), do not use light signals at all, but rely on chemical signals (pheromones) instead. In contrast to bioluminescent fireflies, the fireflies that rely on pheromones during mate search, tend to be active during the day. Interestingly, the ability to generate bioluminescence did not just evolve once in firefly history. Among our 339 firefly species, we found up to 8 independent origins of adult bioluminescence (glows or flashes) from dark fireflies, 6 origins of glowing signals, and up to 9 independent origins of flashing signals. In some cases, fireflies lost their light signals and went back to exclusively using pheromones. This raises interesting questions about how and why these different mating signals evolved and why they changed during firefly evolution, resulting into the amazing diversity of light displays enjoyed by people across the world.

The firefly family tree will give researchers across the world a valuable tool to ask important research questions not only about firefly mating signals, but also how (and why) other firefly traits have evolved, leading to significant insights into what helps these beetles survive in their different environments. We will publish the molecular tools we developed to generate our large family tree, which will allow other firefly researchers (and those studying closely related beetle groups) to utilize these tools and add additional species, allowing the research community to answer more and more research questions.

Bioluminescent fireflies emit their mating signals with their light organ, consisting of two specialized abdominal segments. Different species have very different light organ shapes and sizes that cover only parts of (dots, bars) or their entire abdominal segments. We found that this shape changes frequently on the family tree, and it is currently a mystery why this diversity evolved and how it relates to signal brightness and detectability. The worldwide family tree will give researchers are starting point for designing studies to answer these questions.

Another focus of our project was the sense of smell of fireflies. Male fireflies detect and track pheromones released by their females to locate them. In diurnal species where males rely exclusively on pheromones to find a female, males tend to have elaborate antennae. Firefly antennae are covered in thousands of tiny sensilla, which fireflies use to sense humidity, touch or smell, and has long been assumed that larger antennae translate into more sensors. We used Scanning Electron Microscopy to categorize and count these tiny sensilla across 7 diverse firefly species and we were surprised to learn that fireflies have an unexpected diversity of antennal sensilla, which differ even between closely related species. This suggests that different firefly species may perceive the world very differently from each other. As suspected, based on their mating signals, diurnal fireflies have indeed more olfactory sensilla (including those that detect pheromones), on their antenna than nocturnal fireflies, and male fireflies (detecting pheromones) have more olfactory sensilla than their females (releasing pheromones). For each of the 7 firefly species we identified the sensilla type that most likely functions as a pheromone sensor, which will facilitate future functional testing.

This project trained a postdoctoral researcher (now an Assistant Professor), a graduate student (now a postdoctoral researcher), and several undergraduate students (now in professional schools) in research methods and science communication. We also collaborated with the other two labs in this collaborative project to produce outreach videos that feature our three graduate student researchers and their different research projects, including the resaerch questions they asked, the methods they used, and how science is done. These will be widely distributed and available on YouTube.
